awd_titl_txt: CAREER:   A Late Triassic Origin for Modern Marine Predator-prey Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
Predation is an important driver of ecological structure in modern shallow marine ecosystems, but the development of modern predator-prey dynamics in past oceans are poorly understood.  Many of the most important modern marine predators and their prey animals appeared during the Late Triassic, about 228 ? 202 million years ago. This research will examine the role of predator-prey interactions in building modern-style ecological systems during this time of dramatic environmental change. Student mentorship groups comprised of undergraduates and students from nearby tribal high schools will develop research projects to solve environmental problems using the skills learned as part of the present study. 

The goal of the present research is to quantify the antagonistic relationships between predator and prey taxa from three distinct marine regions during the Late Triassic. Series of fossiliferous bulk samples will be collected from regions in Nevada, Italy, and New Zealand to determine geographic patterns of predator occurrence and abundance, coupled with abundance and morphological pattern data for prey groups. In order to create a temporally- and spatially-resolved faunal dataset reflecting shifting ecological relationships, the three fossiliferous bulk sample sequences will be correlated to each other and to recognized geologic events using multiple chronostratigraphic methods. Paleoecological niche modeling will be used to test the concept of escalation in this predator-prey system, thus allowing for an evaluation of the role of both intrinsic and extrinsic factors in ecological function and health. Results will be made available through public databases, publications, and presentations at conferences by student researchers.

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: The Curators of the University of Missouri
perf_inst.perf_str_addr: 601 Turner Avenue; Turner Avenue Garage, Rm. 201

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The activities funded though this project investigated the role of specialized predators in shaping shallow marine ecosystems during the Late Triassic, addressing outstanding challenges in distinguishing between the influence of environmental condition and biotic interactions. The data revealed that shell-crushing vertebrates played a significant role in shaping benthic communities during the Late Triassic. By analyzing bulk fossil samples from Nevada and New Zealand, the study showed large transitions in potential prey, common shelly invertebrate taxa; immobile seafloor-dwelling animals exhibited the greatest changes in abundance and morphology, favoring species with thicker, larger, and/or rounded shells increasingly throughout this interval. 

In analyzing assemblages of vertebrate microfossils, specialized predators occupied diverse ecological niches. Microvertebrate fossils documented in both studied regions expanded the known spatial and temporal ranges of numerous marine taxa, suggesting that Late Triassic marine vertebrates were more widespread than previously recognized, and that migration of influential vertebrate predators was likely to have been an important factor in the appearance of many new adaptations in shelly marine animals such as cementation and intermittent swimming among bivalves. The increasing presence of shell-crushing predators in both Nevada and New Zealand suggests that their interactions with prey organisms influenced evolutionary trajectories across broad geographic regions. Evidence from the fossil record suggests that prey organisms adapted to increased predation pressure, influencing the composition and structure of marine communities over time.

Beyond predator-prey dynamics, environmental stressors also play a role in shaping these ecosystems, thus it was critical to differentiate between these influences. The presence of other microfossils was used to reconstruct the geochemical conditions of these environments, allowing for better constraints on shifting benthic organisms’ responses to environmental influences in contrast to predator-prey interactions. The latest Triassic saw widespread dysoxia and disruptions in silica cycling, as evidenced by the proliferation of hypersilicified sponge spicules and shifts in biogenic sediments. These geochemical fluctuations likely impacted both predator and prey populations, further influencing marine food webs. 

This research illustrated how shifting abundances of predators contributed to shifts in community structure while also emphasizing the adaptive responses of prey taxa. The findings underscore the importance of predator-prey interactions in driving evolutionary and ecological change in marine ecosystems. This work provides valuable insights into the dynamics of ancient ocean communities, with broader implications for understanding the long-term effects of predator invasions in modern marine environments. The research activities yielded data which was contributed to eight published manuscripts and 41 refereed conference presentations. One graduate student, twenty undergraduate students, seven students from North Dakota tribal high schools and colleges, and two high school students were supported in research projects related to the overall goals of the project, which yielded 32 national conference presentations with student authors and four student co-authored manuscripts. 

 


Last Modified: 03/06/2025
Modified by: Lydia S Tackett
